description: On May 6 it was announced that disinfection of ambulances and medical institutions is carried out in Minsk, Belarus. Since February 2020, several stations have been operation to disinfect ambulances, vehicles that deliver medical personnel to work and home, as well as cars of private individuals transporting people with infectious diseases. The emphasis in the treatment of medical institutions is placed on common areas - corridors, elevators, staircases, bathrooms. Medical disinfectants are also used in offices, to clean tables, chairs, changing tables, washbasins, cabinets, and doors.

On April 7th, in Minsk, Belarus it is required that churches, temples, and monasteries ensure regular washing of hands, the cleaning of premises using disinfectants, and the ventilation of rooms, as well as carrying out disinfecting treatment of furniture and door handles, icons which parishioners touch, and utensils and liturgical vessels.

In Minsk, Belarus, starting April 7th existing sanitary maintenance of public transportation (buses, electric buses, trolleybuses, trams, metro rolling stock, minibuses, as well as major bus stations and minor bus stations) will be strengthened. Preventive and disinfection measures will be carried out in the provision of services for passengers traveling by road and ensuring the availability of conditions at bus stations to ensure that employees and passengers observe personal hygiene rules.

On April 8th it was announced that in Minsk, Belarus, entrances of residential buildings will be cleaned using disinfection on a daily basis and public transport must pass through mandatory disinfection.

On June 17 in Belarus, the Ministry of Health published recommendations for the prevention of COVID-19 in health resort organizations/sanatoriums. Recommendations include breaks between arrivals of vacationers for general cleaning and disinfection. If the institution has its own transport, which provides services to vacationers (transfer, excursions), it should be sanitized after use. It is necessary to organize daily wet cleaning of premises using household detergents or disinfectants with the treatment of all surfaces. Surfaces include door handles, handrails, elevator buttons, tables, chairs, other pieces of furniture, sanitary equipment, telephones, office equipment panels and other items that people touch. Daily disinfection is also necessary in regards to the surfaces of equipment and elements of small architectural forms on the street (examples include the gym, sports grounds, gazebos, benches, beach equipment). It is recommended to ventilate the premises regularly. Dispensers with an antiseptic (disinfectant) hand sanitizer (preferably alcohol-based) should be regularly maintained. After appointments for medical services or procedures, it is necessary to disinfect the surfaces and ventilate the room.
On September 29 it was announced in Minsk, Belarus that dispensers with antiseptics are installed in public places.

Belarus. 18 of March 2020 The Ministry of transport has restricted rest and food points for drivers and refuelling of vehicles for carriers passing through the territory of the Republic of Belarus. Stop points should be equipped with personal protective equipment. The restrictions will take effect on March 19

description: Belarus. On 31of March Belarus has introduced a temporary ban on the export of buckwheat, buckwheat groats, onions and garlic. These goods are not allowed to be exported regardless of their country of origin, including when placed under customs procedures for export, temporary export, processing outside the customs territory and re-export. The ban is valid until June 31, 2020
type_text: Temporary ban on the export of certain products (onions, garlic, buckwheat). These goods are not allowed to be exported regardless of their country of origin, including when placed under customs procedures for export, temporary export, processing outside the customs territory and re-export. The resolution is valid for three months.

description: On June 11, changes were made to the list of countries upon arrival from which it is necessary to be in self-isolation for 14 days in Belarus. Of the 169 countries that were included in the list in March, 37 countries that have improved their epidemiological situation are excluded. These are as follows: Austria, Albania, Belgium, Bulgaria, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Hungary, Germany, Greece, Denmark, Ireland, Iceland, Spain, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Malta, Moldova, Monaco, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, North Macedonia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Finland, France, Croatia, Montenegro, Czech Republic, Switzerland, Sweden, Estonia and China. People who came from these countries are not required to be in self-isolation for 14 days from the date of arrival in Belarus. At the same time, foreigners arriving in Belarus must have a negative PCR result when crossing the border - a study performed no later than two days before the date of crossing the border.

description: On June 17 it was announced that the Ministry of Health in Belarus recommends that customers arriving to a sanatorium who are found to have a high temperature are quarantined at the sanatorium. It is recommended to accept citizens arriving from abroad if there is information (certificate) about the lack of contact with a person infected with COVID-19 within the last 14 days before the date of departure and a negative laboratory test for COVID-19 infection (it must be carried out no later than two days before arrival).
type_sub_cat: Quarantine outside the home or government facility (i.e. quarantine in a hotel)

description: On June 11, changes were made to the list of countries upon arrival from which it is necessary to be in self-isolation for 14 days in Belarus. Of the 169 countries that were included in the list in March, 37 countries that have improved their epidemiological situation are excluded. These are as follows: Austria, Albania, Belgium, Bulgaria, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Hungary, Germany, Greece, Denmark, Ireland, Iceland, Spain, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Malta, Moldova, Monaco, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, North Macedonia, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Finland, France, Croatia, Montenegro, Czech Republic, Switzerland, Sweden, Estonia and China. People who came from these countries are not required to be in self-isolation for 14 days from the date of arrival in Belarus. At the same time, foreigners arriving in Belarus must have a negative PCR result when crossing the border - a study performed no later than two days before the date of crossing the border.

description: The isolation period is only 10 days for those arriving from countries with an unfavorable epidemic situation, and for those who are established as first-level contact with infected COVID-19. On October 13 it was announced that the list of persons who are not subject to the 10 day self-isolation upon arrival in Belarus from countries in which cases of COVID-19 are registered has been expanded. These are the heads and members of official delegations; those who travel through Belarus in transit and leave the country within 24 hours; arrived from business trips; persons who transport stem cells, organs for transplantation. Foreigners who arrived from countries not included by the Ministry of Health on the list of countries where COVID-19 cases are registered must present a negative COVID-19 test when entering Belarus, performed no later than 72 hours before the date of crossing the border. This does not apply to foreigners and stateless persons permanently residing in Belarus. Also, citizens in self-isolation are allowed, in case of emergency, to visit a health care organization to receive emergency and (or) emergency medical care. Quarantine still applies to other countries previously listed.

description: On October 8 in Belarus, the Ministry of Health will reduce the isolation period to 10 days for those arriving from countries with an unfavorable epidemic situation, and for those who are established as first-level contact with infected COVID-19. Quarantine still applies to other countries previously listed.

description: The Ministry of Health updated the list of countries in which cases of infection with COVID-19 are registered. Since October 21, the list includes 28 countries that were previously excluded from it. These are France, Belgium, Luxembourg, Moldova, United States of America, Lebanon, Netherlands, Iceland, Czech Republic, United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Romania, North Macedonia, Ireland, Portugal, Slovenia, Slovakia, Tunisia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Switzerland, Poland, Lithuania, Sweden, Denmark, Liechtenstein, Malta, Bulgaria and Canada. People arriving from these countries are required to be in self-isolation for 10 calendar days after arriving in Belarus. Quarantine also still applies to other countries previously listed.

description: The isolation period is only 10 days for those arriving from countries with an unfavorable epidemic situation, and for those who are established as first-level contact with infected COVID-19. On October 13 it was announced that the list of persons who are not subject to the 10 day self-isolation upon arrival in Belarus from countries in which cases of COVID-19 are registered has been expanded. These are the heads and members of official delegations; those who travel through Belarus in transit and leave the country within 24 hours; arrived from business trips; persons who transport stem cells, organs for transplantation. Foreigners who arrived from countries not included by the Ministry of Health on the list of countries where COVID-19 cases are registered must present a negative COVID-19 test when entering Belarus, performed no later than 72 hours before the date of crossing the border. This does not apply to foreigners and stateless persons permanently residing in Belarus. Also, citizens in self-isolation are allowed, in case of emergency, to visit a health care organization to receive emergency and (or) emergency medical care. Quarantine still applies to other countries previously listed.

description: In Minsk, Belarus starting on April 7th, it was announced that the managers of hotel business, trade, public catering, social services, organizations providing postal services, as well as life support services of the city and other organizations of all forms of ownership providing services to the population, need to organize daily thermometry of employees before starting work, keep track of the results in a journal and remove employees from work in case of temperature increase.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions_This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: Starting on April 7 in Minsk, Belarus, events, group presentations, tastings, promotions, etc. are not allowed in shopping and entertainment centers and shops.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions

description: Starting April 7th, in Minsk, Belarus, the technological break at public catering facilities after 3:00 PM should be at least 60 minutes for the ongoing disinfection of premises and equipment.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions_This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: Starting April 7th, in Minsk, Belarus the reception of visitors in hairdressing salons, tattoo parlors, beauty salons, permanent make-up salons and other similar locations in the beauty industry should be carried out only by appointment with an interval between clients of at least 5 minutes and with personnel subject to a mask regimen.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Personal Grooming Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: On April 7th in Minsk, Belarus, it is announced that organizations of all forms of ownership in premises with workers staying, are required to ensure: wet cleaning with detergents and disinfectants, effective operation of ventilation and air conditioning systems in compliance with indoor climate conditions, and preventing unauthorized persons from visiting the premises of organizations. They must also limit the number of workers per shift, splitting up their flows in the case of two or three shifts and providing for a break that lasts at least 30 minutes.
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions_This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: Belarus, April 8 Minsk authorities impose restrictions of non-essential business: restaurants/cafes must hold a distance between customers, comply with sanitary rules, measure the temperature of employees of the hotel business and ensure rules for accommodating guests, the beauty industry needs to change the schedule and take bigger breaks between clients to avoid overcrowding.

description: 12 of March Belarus established restrictions on mass gatherings. This applies to cultural, sports and scientific mass events with international participation.
Belarus, April 8, Minsk authorities impose restrictions of mass gatherings: Exhibitions, presentations, fairs, and other mass events have been canceled.

On June 17 in Belarus, the Ministry of Health recommended to limit cultural events (for example, organized excursions) in indoor and other closed spaces for the prevention of COVID-19 in health resort organizations/sanatoriums.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On August 15 it was announced in Belarus that the holding of mass events must be coordinated with local authorities.

On August 18 it was recommended by the Minsk City Executive Committee in Belarus, to hold fairs, exhibitions, presentations and other events with the observance of social distancing and the use of masks and gloves by staff.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Belarus, April 8, Minsk authorities impose restrictions of mass gatherings: Exhibitions, presentations, fairs, and other mass events have been canceled.

On September 25 it was announced in Belarus that some of the events of the Union State that were planned for 2020 in the field of culture and sports have been postponed to a later date. These include the festivals "Youth for the Union State" and "Creativity of the Young," which are a tourist gathering of students of the Union State and a meeting of young ecologists, and a sports day for children and youth, respectively.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Since June 5th, intervals of public transport have been decreased during rush hours in Minsk, Belarus. In the morning rush hours, the number of buses on routes No. 115E, 127, 144C, 159 was increased by 1 unit per each, from 6:30 to 8:30 and from 17:00 to 19:00 the interval of train traffic was reduced from 3 minutes to 2.5 minutes on both the first and second line of the metro line.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on ridership of subways and trams

description: Since June 5th, intervals of public transport have been decreased during rush hours in Minsk, Belarus. In the morning rush hours, the number of buses on routes No. 115E, 127, 144C, 159 was increased by 1 unit per each, from 6:30 to 8:30 and from 17:00 to 19:00 the interval of train traffic was reduced from 3 minutes to 2.5 minutes on both the first and second line of the metro line.

Starting on June 13th, the subway train interval will be reduced by one minute on weekends in Minsk, Belarus. As such, more trains will go on both lines of the subway from 7:00 to 20:00 every weekend and as necessary, rolling stock will be added to certain routes. Currently, the interval of train traffic in the specified period is from 5 to 6 minutes on the 1st line on Saturday and from 6.5 to 7.5 minutes on Sunday; on the 2nd line - from 6 to 6.5 minutes on Saturday and from 6.5 to 7 minutes on Sunday.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on ridership of subways and trams

description: On June 17 in Belarus, the Ministry of Health published recommendations for the prevention of COVID-19 in health resort organizations/sanatoriums. Recommendations include one-time arrival of vacationers and the use of signal markings ad the check-in counter which informs vacationers that they must be distanced at the counter during their check-in and check-out. In canteens, tables must be arranged to be placed at least at a 1.5-2 m distance from each other. It is recommended to reduce the number of people simultaneously in the dining room. When organizing food through the distribution line, the operation of a buffet or a store on the floor, signal markings should be applied about the need to maintain a distance. If the organization has its own beach, it is recommended to place beach equipment with a distance of at least 1.5-2 m from each other. In regards to the gym, it is necessary to ensure the distance between the guests, including by arranging the equipment, is at least 1.5-2 m. If the institution has its own transport, which provides services to vacationers (transfer, excursions), it should be filled with respect to distance.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On July 4 it was announced that in Belarus swimming is limited in five recreation areas, and it is prohibited at 12. Social distancing, hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette are recommended in public recreational areas, including beaches. It is advisable to take freshly prepared food with you in individual clean packaging, and to use mainly bottled water for drinking, washing fruits and vegetables.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On September 14 in Minsk, Belarus, it was announced that in order to prevent a worsening of the situation with the incidence of acute respiratory infections (ARI), including COVID-19, simple rules must be followed: use personal protective equipment for the respiratory system in public places, change the mask (preferably a medical disposable) every 2 hours; wash hands with soap and water as often as possible, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer; ventilate the premises as often as possible and carry out wet cleaning; observe respiratory etiquette.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: On September 14 in Minsk, Belarus, it was announced that in order to prevent a worsening of the situation with the incidence of acute respiratory infections (ARI), including COVID-19, simple rules must be followed: keep from each other at a distance of 11.5 m; limit attendance at public events, especially those held in closed rooms; avoid close contact with people with ARI symptoms.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On September 25 it was announced in Belarus that the Ministry of Health recommends the correct use of a mask to protect against infections. Before putting on the mask, you must treat your hands with an antiseptic (disinfectant) agent or wash them with soap. Then, holding the mask by the ties or elastic bands, you need to bring it close to your face with the white side inward and fix it. Respiratory etiquette is important.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: On September 25 it was announced in Belarus that the Ministry of Health recommends observing the rules of social distancing during the period of the rise of acute respiratory infections, including COVID-19 infection. When leaving a place of residence in situations where it is necessary, it is worth reducing contact with other people and maintaining a 1.5-meter distance (social distance) from each other.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On September 14 in Minsk, Belarus, it was announced that in order to prevent a worsening of the situation with the incidence of acute respiratory infections (ARI), including COVID-19, simple rules must be followed: use personal protective equipment for the respiratory system in public places, change the mask (preferably a medical disposable) every 2 hours; wash hands with soap and water as often as possible, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer; ventilate the premises as often as possible and carry out wet cleaning; observe respiratory etiquette.
